_header: Through glad aspects of the god Cupid
Subjects: Humphrey, duke of Gloucester; Jacqueline of Hainault; historical verse
_description: John Lydgate, on the Duke of Gloucester’s approaching marriage to Jacqueline of Hainault — twenty-seven stanzas rhyme royal and eight-line Envoy

CamTCC600.First Lines:
Thorugh gladde aspectis of þe god CupydeAnd ful acorde of his
                    moder deereffull offt syþes list aforne provydeBy cours eterne of
                    þe sterres cleere…
CamTCC600.Last Lines:
…Sith I it made bytwix hope and dreedOf hoole entent yowe for
                    tyl do plesaunce
CamTCC600.Attributed Title:
And nowe here begynneþe a comendable balade by Lydegate daun Johan at
                    þe reuerence of my lady of holand and of my lord of Gloucestre to fore
                    þe day of þeyre maryage in þe desyrous tyme of þeyre trewe
                    lovyng (p. 158); Of my lord of Gloucestre and of my Ladye of Holand (RT); And
                    þus eendeþe heere þis balade and filowing begynneþe…
                    (p. 164)
CamTCC600.Editions:

         27 (1904): 381-98: 387-93.
MacCracken,  Henry Noble,
                        ed.  
             John Lydgate: The Minor Poems, Vol. II: Secular Poems.
EETS

Hammond,  Eleanor Prescott. 
             English Verse between Chaucer and Surrey.
         Durham, NC: Duke UP, 1927: 145-50.

BLHar2251.First Lines:
Thurgh gladde aspectis of the god CupideAnd ful accorde of his
                    moder deere…
BLHar2251.Last Lines:
…Sith I it made betwixt hope and dredeOf hole entent yow for
                    til do plesaunce

BLAdd29729.First Lines:
Thorugh glad aspectis ofþe god cupydeand full fo[..]rde of his
                    mother dere…
BLAdd29729.Last Lines:
…sith I it made bytwixt hope and dredof hole entent thou for
                    tyll do plesaunce
BLAdd29729.Note:
Third word of second line is written over, the black ink obscures the
                    original and revised lettering; ends ‘finis’ (f. 160).
BLAdd29729.Attributed Title:
And now here begenneth acomendable balade by lydegate daune Iohn at þe
                    reuerence of my lady of heland and of my lord of glouscester to fore þe
                    daye of there maryage in þe desyrous tyme of ther true louynges (f.
                        157v)
